metadata.case_name: Shiam Lal Radhey Lal v. Agra Mahapalika

facts.text: Appellants are partners of the firm Shiam Lal Radhey Lal.
First respondent is Agra Mahapalika; second respondent is Health Officer of Mahapalika.
Military Dairy Farm at Agra possessed wheat flour declared unfit for human consumption; purchased by appellants' firm for use as lehi, manure and ratab for consumption by animals.
Appellants instituted suit against respondents for recovery of Rs. 34,000 as damages grounded on tortious liability.
Trial court decreed the suit; Allahabad High Court reversed the decree and dismissed the suit on May 25, 1962 in Appeal No. 328 of 1950.
Appellants started selling the flour from March 20, 1945.

On May 17, 1945, second respondent reported to Administrator of Nagarpalika that flour was decomposed, deteriorated and unfit for human consumption; admitted firm set up placard stating 'flour is condemned atta and unfit for consumption'.
Nagarpalika reported matter to District Magistrate, Agra.
On July 26, 1945, order issued under s. 144 Cr. P. C. prohibiting appellants from selling flour for one month; extended till September 20, 1945 by order dated September 18, 1945.
Appellants prosecuted for offences under ss. 4 and 14 of U.P. Prevention of Adulteration Act and s. 273 I.P.C.; flour seized by magistrate's order and kept in custody of appellants.

Magistrate acquitted appellants on September 5, 1945; directed that atta is not injurious to public health but needs regulation; ordered Municipal Medical Officer of Health to take possession and regulate disposal considering owner, to prevent use as food; expedite action.

On September 17, 1945, second respondent issued order under s. 244 U.P. Municipalities Act re 2048 bags of atta seized; permitted disposal subject to conditions: approved salesman, separate stock/sales books with buyer details, sell only for lehi to book-binders/shoe-merchants, weekly returns.
Appellants' letter dated September 22, 1945: requested permission to sell for animal food after mixing gram dal chuni; noted suffering loss due to wrongful seizure and delay affecting quality.
Respondents' letter dated September 27, 1945: approved Nanu Mal as salesman; emphasized compliance with Sep 17 directions; no reply to animal food request.
Second respondent's letter dated October 6, 1945: permitted sale for animal food under certain conditions.

Second respondent's directions dated October 8, 1945 under s. 244: not for dairy animals; no less than one full bag per individual; label warning unfit for human consumption, for animals only; access for inspection.
Appellants had placed sign-board stating flour unfit for human consumption; oral evidence supports; admitted by respondents; mixed maize flour but not for human sale.
Respondents denied liability; action bona fide, public safety/health, per magistrate directions; appellants took steps to prevent human consumption sale.

legal_issues.text: Whether the respondents are liable to pay damages in the circumstances of the case.
If liable, what is the quantum of their liability.

petitioner_arguments.text: Respondents initially stopped sale and imposed restrictions under s.244 U.P. Municipalities Act (Sep 17 to Oct 8, 1945) which effectively prevented sale; caused loss due to delay; orders invalid and mala fide.

respondent_arguments.text: Action bona fide in interest of public safety/health, pursuant to magistrate directions; orders under s.244 valid.
respondent_arguments.legal_basis: Section 244 U.P. Municipalities Act; Magistrate order Sep 5, 1945

court_reasoning.text: No liability for stoppage July 26 to Sep 20, 1945 as per magistrate s.144 CrPC order.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Magistrate order valid during that period.

court_reasoning.text: Magistrate's Sep 5, 1945 order affords no protection as magistrate had no power to issue it.

S.244(1) U.P. Municipalities Act applies only if article of food appears intended for human consumption and unfit therefor; requires objective facts showing seller's intention for human consumption, not subjective satisfaction of officer; does not cover indirect sale via animals.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Flour sale appeared not intended for human consumption due to placard and evidence.

court_reasoning.text: Evidence shows appellants informed buyers via placard it was unfit for humans; respondents admit; mixing maize not indicative of human sale intent.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Orders under s.244 invalid despite bona fides.

court_reasoning.text: Respondents liable for loss caused by invalid orders post Sep 20, 1945.
High Court gave no finding on quantum.

holdings.text: Respondents not liable for period under s.144 CrPC (July 26-Sep 20, 1945).
Orders under s.244 U.P. Municipalities Act invalid as flour not appearing intended for human consumption; respondents liable for subsequent loss.
Remand to High Court for finding on quantum of damages.

statutes_cited.name: U.P. Municipalities Act
statutes_cited.relevance: Chapter VIII on markets, slaughter houses, sale of food; s.244(1) interpreted as requiring objective appearance of intent for human consumption; orders under s.244 held invalid.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure
statutes_cited.relevance: Prohibited sale July 26-Sep 20, 1945; protected respondents during that period.

outcome.summary: Appeal allowed; High Court judgment and decree set aside; case remanded to High Court for deciding issue of damages.
outcome.relief_granted: Liability of respondents established; quantum of damages to be determined by High Court.
outcome.costs: Costs will abide the decision of the High Court on the question of damages.

key_quotes.text: "Since this Atta is not injurious to public health and it is not possible to prevent its reaching consumers even though the accused had best intention without effective regulation I order that the entire Atta still be taken possession of by the Municipal medical officer of Health who will kindly regulate its disposal in consonance with considerations to the owner as is necessary to prevent its being used as food."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Magistrate's acquittal order directing regulation, later held to lack legal power.

key_quotes.text: The phrase 'an article of food or drink appears to be intended for the consumption of man' does not contemplate any subjective satisfaction. The seller should intend to sell an article of food for human consumption. His intention is an objective fact.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core interpretation rendering s.244 orders invalid.

key_quotes.text: It is immaterial that the respondents had acted bona fide and in the interest of preservation of public health. Their motive may be good but their orders are illegal.
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Establishes tortious liability despite good intentions.
